metadata.title: Convert Pounds per Cubic Foot to Kilogram per Cubic Meter – Density Converter
metadata.description: Convert density from US customary lb/ft³ to SI metric kg/m³, enabling translation of North American engineering specifications to international standards and global material documentation.

introduction: This converter transforms density measurements from pounds per cubic foot (US customary unit) to kilograms per cubic meter (SI metric standard), enabling translation of North American engineering specifications to international standards. It is designed for engineers, architects, procurement specialists, and materials professionals adapting US-standard specifications for global use.

The pounds per cubic foot is the traditional density unit in North American construction, mechanical engineering, and materials industries. The kilogram per cubic meter is the universal SI standard for scientific research, international technical documentation, and most engineering applications outside North America. Understanding this conversion is essential for international material sourcing and project collaboration.

This converter uses the precise conversion factor of 1 lb/ft³ = 16.0184634 kg/m³, enabling accurate density conversions for international engineering documentation, material procurement from global suppliers, regulatory compliance, and technical specification translation across different measurement systems.
methodology: The relationship between lb/ft³ and kg/m³ is based on mass and volume unit conversions: 1 pound = 0.453592 kg and 1 cubic foot = 0.0283168 m³. This converter uses the precise conversion factor: 1 lb/ft³ = 16.0184634 kg/m³. The inverse is: 1 kg/m³ ≈ 0.0624280 lb/ft³.

To convert pounds per cubic foot to kilograms per cubic meter, multiply the density in lb/ft³ by 16.0184634. For example, 62.43 lb/ft³ = 1,000 kg/m³ (water), 490 lb/ft³ = 7,850 kg/m³ (steel), and 168.6 lb/ft³ = 2,700 kg/m³ (aluminum). This conversion is essential for international technical documentation.

Material specifications originating from North American suppliers often use lb/ft³. Converting these values to kg/m³ allows seamless integration into international projects, global material databases, and multi-national engineering documentation. Accurate conversion prevents material mix-ups and specification errors.

This converter provides precise density conversions for international material sourcing, specification translation, regulatory compliance verification, and collaborative engineering across borders. Use accurate density values for material procurement, design verification, and documentation in multinational engineering projects.
examples: Example 1 – Water reference: Water at 62.43 lb/ft³ converts to the SI standard 1,000 kg/m³, confirming specification accuracy when translating US documentation to international standards.
Example 2 – American structural steel: Steel density of 490 lb/ft³ in North American specifications converts to 7,850 kg/m³ for use in European projects and international material databases.
Example 3 – Aluminum specifications: Aluminum at 170 lb/ft³ in US engineering standards converts to 2,720 kg/m³ for aerospace projects requiring SI metric documentation.
Example 4 – Concrete: Concrete at 150 lb/ft³ in North American building codes converts to 2,400 kg/m³ for international construction specifications and design verification.

faqs.question: What is the precise conversion factor from lb/ft³ to kg/m³?
faqs.answer: The precise conversion is: 1 lb/ft³ = 16.0184634 kg/m³. This factor is derived from standard definitions: 1 pound = 0.453592 kg and 1 cubic foot = 0.0283168 m³.

faqs.question: Why is this conversion important for material sourcing?
faqs.answer: Materials supplied from North American vendors use lb/ft³ specifications, while international and SI-standard suppliers use kg/m³. Converting between these units prevents specification mismatches when sourcing globally.

faqs.question: How can I verify my conversion is correct?
faqs.answer: Use known reference values: water should be 62.43 lb/ft³ or 1,000 kg/m³; steel should be 490 lb/ft³ or 7,850 kg/m³. Verify your converted values against these standards to catch conversion errors.

faqs.question: What are typical density values in lb/ft³ for common materials?
faqs.answer: Water (62.4 lb/ft³), wood (30-60 lb/ft³), concrete (140-155 lb/ft³), aluminum (170 lb/ft³), steel (490 lb/ft³), copper (560 lb/ft³). These values help verify accuracy and material selection.

faqs.question: Why do different regions use different density units?
faqs.answer: Historical convention. North America adopted imperial units before SI was established globally. Many existing North American codes, standards, and calculations still use lb/ft³, requiring conversion when working internationally.

faqs.question: How do I ensure consistency when using materials specified in both units?
faqs.answer: Always verify converted values against primary sources. If a material has specifications in both units, cross-check them using this converter. Significant discrepancies indicate errors requiring clarification with suppliers.

faqs.question: What is the relationship between density and structural weight?
faqs.answer: Weight = Density × Volume. A material's density directly determines how much it weighs for a given volume. This relationship is critical for structural design, foundation sizing, and transportation logistics.

faqs.question: How does density affect manufacturing and transport costs?
faqs.answer: Denser materials cost more to transport due to weight. Manufacturing processes may also require density-specific handling (heat treatment, casting). Understanding density is essential for cost estimation and logistics planning.

glossary.definition: The traditional US customary unit of density, expressing mass in pounds per unit volume of one cubic foot. Still widely used in North American engineering, construction, and mechanical industries.
The SI international standard unit of density, expressing mass in kilograms per unit volume of one cubic meter. The official unit for scientific research and international engineering.
The process of converting technical specifications from one unit system to another while preserving accuracy and meaning. Critical for international material sourcing and collaborative engineering.
The process of acquiring raw materials or components from suppliers. Accurate specification translation ensures correct material sourcing across international supply chains.

Adherence to standards and codes required by government or industry organizations. Many international projects require documentation in SI metric units, necessitating conversion from US customary units.
